trans-unit.source: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI
trans-unit.target: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI

trans-unit.source: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI
trans-unit.target: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI
trans-unit.target: Migrating from DNX to .NET Core CLI

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: With RC1 release of .NET Core and ASP.NET Core 1.0, we introduced DNX tooling to the world.
trans-unit.target: With RC1 release of .NET Core and ASP.NET Core 1.0, we introduced DNX tooling to the world.

trans-unit.source: With RC2 release of .NET Core and ASP.NET Core 1.0 we transitioned to the .NET Core CLI.
trans-unit.target: With RC2 release of .NET Core and ASP.NET Core 1.0 we transitioned to the .NET Core CLI.

trans-unit.source: As a slight refresher, let's recap what DNX was about.
trans-unit.target: As a slight refresher, let's recap what DNX was about.

trans-unit.source: DNX was a runtime and a toolset used to build .NET Core and, more specifically, ASP.NET Core 1.0 applications.
trans-unit.target: DNX was a runtime and a toolset used to build .NET Core and, more specifically, ASP.NET Core 1.0 applications.

trans-unit.source: It consisted of 3 main pieces:
trans-unit.target: It consisted of 3 main pieces:

trans-unit.source: DNVM - an install script for obtaining DNX
trans-unit.target: DNVM - an install script for obtaining DNX

trans-unit.source: DNX (Dotnet Execution Runtime) - the runtime that executes your code
trans-unit.target: DNX (Dotnet Execution Runtime) - the runtime that executes your code

trans-unit.source: DNU (Dotnet Developer Utility) - tooling for managing dependencies, building and publishing your applications
trans-unit.target: DNU (Dotnet Developer Utility) - tooling for managing dependencies, building and publishing your applications

trans-unit.source: With the introduction of the CLI, all of the above are now part of a single toolset.
trans-unit.target: With the introduction of the CLI, all of the above are now part of a single toolset.

trans-unit.source: However, since DNX was available in RC1 timeframe, you might have projects that were built using it that you would want to move off to the new CLI tooling.
trans-unit.target: However, since DNX was available in RC1 timeframe, you might have projects that were built using it that you would want to move off to the new CLI tooling.

trans-unit.source: This migration guide will cover the essentials on how to migrate projects off of DNX and onto .NET Core CLI.
trans-unit.target: This migration guide will cover the essentials on how to migrate projects off of DNX and onto .NET Core CLI.

trans-unit.source: If you are just starting a project on .NET Core from scratch, you can freely skip this document.
trans-unit.target: If you are just starting a project on .NET Core from scratch, you can freely skip this document.

trans-unit.source: Main changes in the tooling
trans-unit.target: Main changes in the tooling

trans-unit.source: There are some general changes in the tooling that should be outlined first.
trans-unit.target: There are some general changes in the tooling that should be outlined first.

trans-unit.source: No more DNVM
trans-unit.target: No more DNVM

trans-unit.source: DNVM, short for *DotNet Version Manager* was a bash/PowerShell script used to install a DNX on your machine.
trans-unit.target: DNVM, short for *DotNet Version Manager* was a bash/PowerShell script used to install a DNX on your machine.

trans-unit.source: It helped users get the DNX they need from the feed they specified (or default ones) as well as mark a certain DNX "active", which would put it on the $PATH for the given session.
trans-unit.target: It helped users get the DNX they need from the feed they specified (or default ones) as well as mark a certain DNX "active", which would put it on the $PATH for the given session.

trans-unit.source: This would allow you to use the various tools.
trans-unit.target: This would allow you to use the various tools.

trans-unit.source: DNVM was discontinued because its feature set was made redundant by changes coming in the .NET Core CLI tools.
trans-unit.target: DNVM was discontinued because its feature set was made redundant by changes coming in the .NET Core CLI tools.

trans-unit.source: The CLI tools come packaged in two main ways, as was explained in the [overview document](tools/index.md#installation):
trans-unit.target: The CLI tools come packaged in two main ways, as was explained in the [overview document](tools/index.md#installation):

trans-unit.source: Native installers for a given platform
trans-unit.target: Native installers for a given platform

trans-unit.source: Install script for other situations (like CI servers)
trans-unit.target: Install script for other situations (like CI servers)

trans-unit.source: Given this, the DNVM install features are not needed.
trans-unit.target: Given this, the DNVM install features are not needed.

trans-unit.source: But what about the runtime selection features?
trans-unit.target: But what about the runtime selection features?

trans-unit.source: You reference a runtime in your `project.json` by adding a package of a certain version to your dependencies.
trans-unit.target: You reference a runtime in your `project.json` by adding a package of a certain version to your dependencies.

trans-unit.source: With this change, your application will be able to use the new runtime bits.
trans-unit.target: With this change, your application will be able to use the new runtime bits.

trans-unit.source: Getting these bits to your machine is the same as with the CLI: you install the runtime via one of the native installers it supports or via its install script.
trans-unit.target: Getting these bits to your machine is the same as with the CLI: you install the runtime via one of the native installers it supports or via its install script.

trans-unit.source: Different commands
trans-unit.target: Different commands

trans-unit.source: If you were using DNX, you used some commands from one of its three parts (DNX, DNU or DNVM).
trans-unit.target: If you were using DNX, you used some commands from one of its three parts (DNX, DNU or DNVM).

trans-unit.source: With the CLI, some of these commands change, some are not available and some are the same but have slightly different semantics.
trans-unit.target: With the CLI, some of these commands change, some are not available and some are the same but have slightly different semantics.

trans-unit.source: The table below shows the mapping between the DNX/DNU commands and their CLI counterparts.
trans-unit.target: The table below shows the mapping between the DNX/DNU commands and their CLI counterparts.

trans-unit.source: DNX command
trans-unit.target: DNX command

trans-unit.source: CLI command
trans-unit.target: CLI command

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: dnx run
trans-unit.target: dnx run

trans-unit.source: dotnet run
trans-unit.target: dotnet run

trans-unit.source: Run code from source.
trans-unit.target: Run code from source.

trans-unit.source: dnu build
trans-unit.target: dnu build

trans-unit.source: dotnet build
trans-unit.target: dotnet build

trans-unit.source: Build an IL binary of your code.
trans-unit.target: Build an IL binary of your code.

trans-unit.source: dnu pack
trans-unit.target: dnu pack

trans-unit.source: dotnet pack
trans-unit.target: dotnet pack

trans-unit.source: Package up a NuGet package of your code.
trans-unit.target: Package up a NuGet package of your code.

trans-unit.source: dnx \[command] (for example, "dnx web")
trans-unit.target: dnx \[command] (for example, "dnx web")

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: In DNX world, run a command as defined in the project.json.
trans-unit.target: In DNX world, run a command as defined in the project.json.

trans-unit.source: dnu install
trans-unit.target: dnu install

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: In the DNX world, install a package as a dependency.
trans-unit.target: In the DNX world, install a package as a dependency.

trans-unit.source: dnu restore
trans-unit.target: dnu restore

trans-unit.source: dotnet restore
trans-unit.target: dotnet restore

trans-unit.source: Restore dependencies specified in your project.json.
trans-unit.target: Restore dependencies specified in your project.json.

trans-unit.source: dnu publish
trans-unit.target: dnu publish

trans-unit.source: dotnet publish
trans-unit.target: dotnet publish

trans-unit.source: Publish your application for deployment in one of the three forms (portable, portable with native and standalone).
trans-unit.target: Publish your application for deployment in one of the three forms (portable, portable with native and standalone).

trans-unit.source: dnu wrap
trans-unit.target: dnu wrap

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: In DNX world, wrap a project.json in csproj.
trans-unit.target: In DNX world, wrap a project.json in csproj.

trans-unit.source: dnu commands
trans-unit.target: dnu commands

trans-unit.source: N/A
trans-unit.target: N/A

trans-unit.source: In DNX world, manage the globally installed commands.
trans-unit.target: In DNX world, manage the globally installed commands.

trans-unit.source: (\*) - these features are not supported in the CLI by design.
trans-unit.target: (\*) - these features are not supported in the CLI by design.

trans-unit.source: DNX features that are not supported
trans-unit.target: DNX features that are not supported

trans-unit.source: As the table above shows, there are features from the DNX world that we decided not to support in the CLI, at least for the time being.
trans-unit.target: As the table above shows, there are features from the DNX world that we decided not to support in the CLI, at least for the time being.

trans-unit.source: This section will go through the most important ones and outline the rationale behind not supporting them as well as workarounds if you do need them.
trans-unit.target: This section will go through the most important ones and outline the rationale behind not supporting them as well as workarounds if you do need them.

trans-unit.source: Global commands
trans-unit.target: Global commands

trans-unit.source: DNU came with a concept called "global commands".
trans-unit.target: DNU came with a concept called "global commands".

trans-unit.source: These were, essentially, console applications packaged up as NuGet packages with a shell script that would invoke the DNX you specified to run the application.
trans-unit.target: These were, essentially, console applications packaged up as NuGet packages with a shell script that would invoke the DNX you specified to run the application.

trans-unit.source: The CLI does not support this concept.
trans-unit.target: The CLI does not support this concept.

trans-unit.source: It does, however, support the concept of adding per-project commands that can be invoked using the familiar `dotnet <command>` syntax.
trans-unit.target: It does, however, support the concept of adding per-project commands that can be invoked using the familiar `dotnet <command>` syntax.

trans-unit.source: More about this can be found in the [extensibility overview](tools/index.md#extensibility).
trans-unit.target: More about this can be found in the [extensibility overview](tools/index.md#extensibility).

trans-unit.source: Installing dependencies
trans-unit.target: Installing dependencies

trans-unit.source: As of v1, the .NET Core CLI tools don't have an `install` command for installing dependencies.
trans-unit.target: As of v1, the .NET Core CLI tools don't have an `install` command for installing dependencies.

trans-unit.source: In order to install a package from NuGet, you would need to add it as a dependency to your `project.json` file and then run `dotnet restore`.
trans-unit.target: In order to install a package from NuGet, you would need to add it as a dependency to your `project.json` file and then run `dotnet restore`.

trans-unit.source: Running your code
trans-unit.target: Running your code

trans-unit.source: There are two main ways to run your code.
trans-unit.target: There are two main ways to run your code.

trans-unit.source: One is from source, with `dotnet run`.
trans-unit.target: One is from source, with `dotnet run`.

trans-unit.source: Unlike `dnx run`, this will not do any in-memory compilation.
trans-unit.target: Unlike `dnx run`, this will not do any in-memory compilation.

trans-unit.source: It will actually invoke `dotnet build` to build your code and then run the built binary.
trans-unit.target: It will actually invoke `dotnet build` to build your code and then run the built binary.

trans-unit.source: Another way is using the `dotnet` itself to run your code.
trans-unit.target: Another way is using the `dotnet` itself to run your code.

trans-unit.source: This is done by providing a path to your assembly: `dotnet path/to/an/assembly.dll`.
trans-unit.target: This is done by providing a path to your assembly: `dotnet path/to/an/assembly.dll`.

trans-unit.source: Migrating your DNX project to .NET Core CLI
trans-unit.target: Migrating your DNX project to .NET Core CLI

trans-unit.source: In addition to using new commands when working with your code, there are three major things left in migrating from DNX:
trans-unit.target: In addition to using new commands when working with your code, there are three major things left in migrating from DNX:

trans-unit.source: Migrate the `global.json` file if you have it to be able to use CLI.
trans-unit.target: Migrate the `global.json` file if you have it to be able to use CLI.

trans-unit.source: Migrating the project file (`project.json`) itself to the CLI tooling.
trans-unit.target: Migrating the project file (`project.json`) itself to the CLI tooling.

trans-unit.source: Migrating off of any DNX APIs to their BCL counterparts.
trans-unit.target: Migrating off of any DNX APIs to their BCL counterparts.

trans-unit.source: Changing the global.json file
trans-unit.target: Changing the global.json file

trans-unit.source: The `global.json` file acts like a solution file for both the RC1 and RC2 (or later) projects.
trans-unit.target: The `global.json` file acts like a solution file for both the RC1 and RC2 (or later) projects.

trans-unit.source: In order for the CLI tools (as well as Visual Studio) to differentiate between RC1 and later versions, they use the `"sdk": { "version" }` property to make the distinction which project is RC1 or later.
trans-unit.target: In order for the CLI tools (as well as Visual Studio) to differentiate between RC1 and later versions, they use the `"sdk": { "version" }` property to make the distinction which project is RC1 or later.

trans-unit.source: If `global.json` doesn't have this node at all, it is assumed to be the latest.
trans-unit.target: If `global.json` doesn't have this node at all, it is assumed to be the latest.

trans-unit.source: In order to update the `global.json` file, either remove the property or set it to the exact version of the tools that you wish to use, in this case **1.0.0-preview2-003121**:
trans-unit.target: In order to update the `global.json` file, either remove the property or set it to the exact version of the tools that you wish to use, in this case **1.0.0-preview2-003121**:

trans-unit.source: Migrating the project file
trans-unit.target: Migrating the project file

trans-unit.source: The CLI and DNX both use the same basic project system based on `project.json` file.
trans-unit.target: The CLI and DNX both use the same basic project system based on `project.json` file.

trans-unit.source: The syntax and the semantics of the project file are pretty much the same, with small differences based on the scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The syntax and the semantics of the project file are pretty much the same, with small differences based on the scenarios.

trans-unit.source: There are also some changes to the schema which you can see in the [schema file](http://json.schemastore.org/project) or in a more friendly [project.json reference](tools/project-json.md).
trans-unit.target: There are also some changes to the schema which you can see in the [schema file](http://json.schemastore.org/project) or in a more friendly [project.json reference](tools/project-json.md).

trans-unit.source: If you are building a console application, you need to add the following snippet to your project file:
trans-unit.target: If you are building a console application, you need to add the following snippet to your project file:

trans-unit.source: This instructs `dotnet build` to emit an entry point for your application, effectively making your code runnable.
trans-unit.target: This instructs `dotnet build` to emit an entry point for your application, effectively making your code runnable.

trans-unit.source: If you are building a class library, simply omit the above section.
trans-unit.target: If you are building a class library, simply omit the above section.

trans-unit.source: Of course, once you add the above snippet to your `project.json` file, you need to add a static entry point.
trans-unit.target: Of course, once you add the above snippet to your `project.json` file, you need to add a static entry point.

trans-unit.source: With the move off DNX, the DI services it provided are no longer available and thus this needs to be a basic .NET entry point: `static void Main()`.
trans-unit.target: With the move off DNX, the DI services it provided are no longer available and thus this needs to be a basic .NET entry point: `static void Main()`.

trans-unit.source: If you have a "commands" section in your `project.json`, you can remove it.
trans-unit.target: If you have a "commands" section in your `project.json`, you can remove it.

trans-unit.source: Some of the commands that used to exist as DNU commands, such as Entity Framework CLI commands, are being ported to be per-project extensions to the CLI.
trans-unit.target: Some of the commands that used to exist as DNU commands, such as Entity Framework CLI commands, are being ported to be per-project extensions to the CLI.

trans-unit.source: If you built your own commands that you are using in your projects, you need to replace them with CLI extensions.
trans-unit.target: If you built your own commands that you are using in your projects, you need to replace them with CLI extensions.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the `commands` node in `project.json` needs to be replaced by the `tools` node and it needs to list the tools dependencies as explained in the [CLI extensibility section](tools/index.md#extensibility).
trans-unit.target: In this case, the `commands` node in `project.json` needs to be replaced by the `tools` node and it needs to list the tools dependencies as explained in the [CLI extensibility section](tools/index.md#extensibility).

trans-unit.source: After these things are done, you need to decide which type of portability you wish for you app.
trans-unit.target: After these things are done, you need to decide which type of portability you wish for you app.

trans-unit.source: With .NET Core, we have invested into providing a spectrum of portability options that you can choose from.
trans-unit.target: With .NET Core, we have invested into providing a spectrum of portability options that you can choose from.

trans-unit.source: For instance, you may want to have a fully *portable* application or you may want to have a *self-contained* application.
trans-unit.target: For instance, you may want to have a fully *portable* application or you may want to have a *self-contained* application.

trans-unit.source: The portable application option is more like .NET Framework applications work: it needs a shared component to execute it on the target machine (.NET Core).
trans-unit.target: The portable application option is more like .NET Framework applications work: it needs a shared component to execute it on the target machine (.NET Core).

trans-unit.source: The self-contained application doesn't require .NET Core to be installed on the target, but you have to produce one application for each OS you wish to support.
trans-unit.target: The self-contained application doesn't require .NET Core to be installed on the target, but you have to produce one application for each OS you wish to support.

trans-unit.source: These portability types and more are discussed in the [application portability type](app-types.md) document.
trans-unit.target: These portability types and more are discussed in the [application portability type](app-types.md) document.

trans-unit.source: Once you make a call on what type of portability you want, you need to change your targeted framework(s).
trans-unit.target: Once you make a call on what type of portability you want, you need to change your targeted framework(s).

trans-unit.source: If you were writing applications for .NET Core, you were most likely using `dnxcore50` as your targeted framework.
trans-unit.target: If you were writing applications for .NET Core, you were most likely using `dnxcore50` as your targeted framework.

trans-unit.source: With the CLI and the changes that the new [.NET Standard Library](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/net-platform-standard.md) brought, the framework needs to be one of the following:
trans-unit.target: With the CLI and the changes that the new [.NET Standard Library](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/net-platform-standard.md) brought, the framework needs to be one of the following:

trans-unit.source: - if you are writing applications on .NET Core (including ASP.NET Core applications)
trans-unit.target: - if you are writing applications on .NET Core (including ASP.NET Core applications)

trans-unit.source: - if you are writing class libraries for .NET Core
trans-unit.target: - if you are writing class libraries for .NET Core

trans-unit.source: If you are using other `dnx` targets, like `dnx451` you will need to change those as well.
trans-unit.target: If you are using other `dnx` targets, like `dnx451` you will need to change those as well.

trans-unit.source: should be changed to `net451`.
trans-unit.target: should be changed to `net451`.

trans-unit.source: Please refer to the [.NET Standard Library document](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/net-platform-standard.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: Please refer to the [.NET Standard Library document](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/net-platform-standard.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Your `project.json` is now mostly ready.
trans-unit.target: Your `project.json` is now mostly ready.

trans-unit.source: You need to go through your dependencies list and update the dependencies to their newer versions, especially if you are using ASP.NET Core dependencies.
trans-unit.target: You need to go through your dependencies list and update the dependencies to their newer versions, especially if you are using ASP.NET Core dependencies.

trans-unit.source: If you were using separate packages for BCL APIs, you can use the runtime package as explained in the [application portability type](app-types.md) document.
trans-unit.target: If you were using separate packages for BCL APIs, you can use the runtime package as explained in the [application portability type](app-types.md) document.

trans-unit.source: Once you are ready, you can try restoring with `dotnet restore`.
trans-unit.target: Once you are ready, you can try restoring with `dotnet restore`.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the version of your dependencies, you may encounter errors if NuGet cannot resolve the dependencies for one of the targeted frameworks above.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the version of your dependencies, you may encounter errors if NuGet cannot resolve the dependencies for one of the targeted frameworks above.

trans-unit.source: This is a "point-in-time" problem; as time progresses, more and more packages will include support for these frameworks.
trans-unit.target: This is a "point-in-time" problem; as time progresses, more and more packages will include support for these frameworks.

trans-unit.source: For now, if you run into this, you can use the `imports` statement within the `framework` node to specify to NuGet that it can restore the packages targeting the framework within the "imports" statement.
trans-unit.target: For now, if you run into this, you can use the `imports` statement within the `framework` node to specify to NuGet that it can restore the packages targeting the framework within the "imports" statement.

trans-unit.source: The restoring errors you get in this case should provide enough information to tell you which frameworks you need to import.
trans-unit.target: The restoring errors you get in this case should provide enough information to tell you which frameworks you need to import.

trans-unit.source: If you are slightly lost or new to this, in general, specifying `dnxcore50` and `portable-net45+win8` in the `imports` statement should do the trick.
trans-unit.target: If you are slightly lost or new to this, in general, specifying `dnxcore50` and `portable-net45+win8` in the `imports` statement should do the trick.

trans-unit.source: The JSON snippet below shows how this looks like:
trans-unit.target: The JSON snippet below shows how this looks like:

trans-unit.source: Running `dotnet build` will show any eventual build errors, though there shouldn't be too many of them.
trans-unit.target: Running `dotnet build` will show any eventual build errors, though there shouldn't be too many of them.

trans-unit.source: After your code is building and running properly, you can test it out with the runner.
trans-unit.target: After your code is building and running properly, you can test it out with the runner.

trans-unit.source: Execute `dotnet <path-to-your-assembly>` and see it run.
trans-unit.target: Execute `dotnet <path-to-your-assembly>` and see it run.
